results.content: To me it seems to hop around a lot. Not sure why I see it that way but it feels disjointed a bit. I'm also 53 and not the fastest typist and I can't really keep up with him.

response.content:
Dear Thomas

Thank you for your review.  The lectures are placed in a logical sequence based on difficulty level and years of teaching this course to 1000s of students.  They build towards the exercises towards the end of each section and the challenges later in the course which you have not reached yet.  However, I am aware that this is not going to suit every single student.  If you have never delved into PHP before then there are some basic fundamentals that need to be covered.  I imagine that this seem a little disjointed to you but there are valid reasons as to why I have the course structured this way.  What you may prefer is learning PHP based on a single project.  There are some benefits to this approach too but my experience has shown that this does not embed content deeply enough. 

In terms of speed, you may not be aware but you can adjust the video player speed to slow things down.  However, I would strongly recommend that you use the pause button during video playback.  I also recommend that you watch each video at least once before trying to follow along if you are a slow typer.  That way you will become familiar with the content.  

If I can help in any other way please feel free to reach out.

Kind regards
Patrick

results.content: I was just hired as an entry level coder for my first programming job involving Sugar CRM. The bad news is I knew nothing about PHP and had not coded much at all in a few years. So this course was perfect for me to get both back into thinking about code and learning about PHP even if I was a bit ashamed to start at the beginner level. I found the challenges quite interesting and thought provoking and the audio sound perfect. The only riff was that I didn't know CSS for the last couple of extension challenges so couldn't do them, but that also made me decide to take a web design course so I could better understand it. I'll definitely be looking into part 2 and eventually 3, and I hope there is an object programming part in the future as that will be super useful for my line of work. Excellent instructor, perfect starting place for beginners or people like me who are first stepping into the field and are rusty on their programming knowledge.

results.content:
This was a wonderful learning experience.

A highlight of the course are the numerous exercises and assignments that help so much with retention of the well-structured content. In many other courses, the learner is "strung along" while the presenters show everything, but never ask the student to actively engage with the material. For some people this approach works well, but I'll just forget the lessons within a week or two if I only sit and listen. I learn best if I am asked to put what is taught into practice and apply it.

This interactive course offers exactly this, and that is what made it such a pleasure. I felt engaged and challenged throughout the course without boredom or frustration. It's an excellent course taught by a skillful teacher with many years of educational background, and it shows. Very recommended.

As for the areas to improve: I would expect something more complex, related to the IDE. So that students can install PHP, setup and run PHP server on their own machines.

I use PHPStorm -  and I think it's closer to real-life projects than codeanywhere :) Anyway, codeanywhere is okay for complete beginners in programming.

response.content:
Thank you for you review, Nataliya. I appreciate you taking the time to provide feedback. You mentioned that you expect something more complex related to the IDE but remember that this is a course for complete beginners.

PHPStorm is a good editor but the reason I do not recommend it is due to the cost (US$199) and the installation requirements and further setup which can be quite complex for a beginner. I have experienced 100s of issues with students using local machine installs, including PHPStorm. Also, remember that this course is about PHP coding and not an in-depth review of an IDE. By keeping things simple it makes it easier for complete beginners to get coding quickly. CodeAnywhere is free for the basic account which gives 2 hours per day. For those wanting even more time the next level can be purchased for a mere $3 for a month which would allow most users to complete the course. I actually recommend to my students not to code for more that 1 hour per day when going through this course. Repeating a little each day is better than cramming everything into many hours in 1 day. CodeAnywhere can also be used from any machine anywhere. It is used by many 1000s of professional developers worldwide so it really is real life too :-)

However, the major benefit of using CodeAnywhere for this course is that I can easily support students as they can share their code or even their developer box. I can quickly log in, fix an issue, talk them through a fix, or even add comments to the code to help them. I can not do this easily (or at all in some cases) on a local machine install.

I have used most online and local machine editors. After many years and seeing many students struggle with local installation issues due to so many operating systems variations, platforms, local machine variables etc I have found that CodeAnywhere is the best option, by far, for the majority of my students including 100% of my face-to-face classes.

I do mention at the beginning of the course that students are free to use any editor they wish...and some do. However, I do not believe it would be wise to start adding multiple videos about various editors as this will confuse beginners. For those wanting to explore there are some great YouTube tutorials.

I hope you enjoy working through the course. If you need anything please feel free to contact me.

Kind regards
Patrick

response.content:
Thank you for your review, Matthew. I am glad you found the course useful. You are free to use ANY platform you wish, many of which are free. The setup video has been updated to provide even more detail about the various options. I go through using CodeAnywhere (free for 7 days and then paid) and also show Visual Studio Code (FREE) and MAMP (FREE). You are free to use any platform you wish. They are both almost identical in the way they look (navigation on the left and code in the main window etc). I do stress that CodeAnywhere is completely optional during the first video. There are just too many other platforms and variations for me to go through all of them and that is why I have selected the 2 best options: 1 paid option which is CodeAnywhere and 1 free option which is Visual Studio Code with MAMP. 
Kind regards
Patrick

results.content:
If you want a no-fluff, straight-to-the-point, engaging, practical, fun and beginners course in PHP, then this is the course you are looking for. 
This course introduces you to the fundamentals of PHP. In no time, you will be writing scripts ranging from fairly simple to complex. The instruction is structured in such a way that you grab the basics very quickly and get to practice what you have learned in practical exercises. 
The instructor's delivery is engaging throughout the entire length of the course and the length of each video is just right so you are not bored and tempted to visit other websites.
I'm giving this course 5 stars because of the practice exercises which does a great deal in developing your mental muscles. 
I could go on and on but all I am trying to say is you aren't going to find any course on Udemy which teaches you the fundamentals of PHP and gives you the confidence to write awesome programs.

Thanks Patrick! You are the man.

response.content:
Many thanks for your review and feedback. It would be possible to make the course longer but then it probably would not be classed as a beginner course...it's hard to strike the right balance with 1000s of students.  In face-to-face classes the current durations seems to work best. There are some courses on PHP on Udemy which are 30+ hours but I personally think these are too long and make it hard to keep motivated. Perhaps other students could offer their opinions in the Q&A. 

The last tasks were not originally part of the course...they were asked for by students as extension tasks without solutions so that they could collaborate with each other. Perhaps an intermediate course would be useful for those who are ready to take the next steps. Anyone interested? Post in the Q&A.

Good luck with the rest of your studies.

I have also played around with PHP and had a pretty good grasp of it, so why would I take this course? Answer because it assumes nothing and to me it taught me more than I thought it would.
Thank you Patrick.
Now onto you next two course in PHP.

results.content: Overall generally very good course. I have no complaints about the instructor he is clear precise and detailed. Very basic info to begin with but fairly good challenges. The tool used is an online tool that requires you to pay after 7 days. though it can be setup locally for free but there is no instruction on how to do this. The task documentation is average but the instructor is very responsive if there are any issues

response.content: Thank you for your review. There may be some confusion as using the CodeAnywhere environment is OPTIONAL. If you want a local install and a FREE option then I do provide free options within the setup video which are Visual Studio Code and MAMP. I show how to set up Visual Studio Code and MAMP and actively encourage users to contact me should they need help. Setup is really easy...just download and install. I have even remotely helped students set up their local environments. I wish you every success with the next stage of your learning. Kind regards. Patrick
